trial_identification.studytitle: Do additional allied health services for rehabilitation reduce length of stay without compromising patient outcomes?
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Does providing additional allied health services for inpatients receiving rehabilitation result in a reduced lenth of stay without compromising patient outcomes compared with inpatients receiving standard rehabilitation services?

conditions.healthcondition: Health conditions will include conditions of patients admitted for rehabilitation. From our pilot data we expect the most common health conditions to be stroke and hip fracture.

interventions.interventions: The experimental group will receive standard rehabilitation from Monday to Friday, plus an additional one hour of physiotherapy and one hour of occupational therapy on Saturday, until discharge from hospital.
interventions.comparator: The control group will receive usual care physiotherapy and occupational therapy from Monday to Friday, until discharge from hospital.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Patient length of stay defined as the number of overnight stays in the rehabilitation unit from the day of admission until the day of discharge from the unit.
Quality of life assessed with the EuroQol questionnaire
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Admission, Discharge, 6 months post discharge, 12 months post discharge

primaryOutcome.outcome: Functional status will be assessed with the Functional Independence Measure (FIM)
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Admission, Discharge, 6 months post discharge, 12 months post discharge

primaryOutcome.outcome: Health service utilisation and costs will be assessed with a health service utilisation questionnaire, and accessing cost data from the rehabilitation facility and Medicare Australia
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Admission, Discharge, 6 months post discharge, 12 months post discharge

primaryOutcome.outcome: Activity levels will be assessed with the ActivPAL (uniaxial accelerometer based activity monitor) for steps, energy expenditure and time upright on a subgroup of rehabilitation patients admitted with a lower limb orthopaedic diagnosis

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Walking speed will be assessed with the 10 metre walk test
Mobility will be assessed with the timed up and go test
Personal Care Participation Assessment and Resource Tool (PC-PART)
Movement, arm function, hand function, walking, and sitting balance in patients with a neurological diagnosis will be assessed with The Modified Motor Assessment scale
Discharge destination, either home, low level residential care, high level residential care, acute hospital transfer

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: 1. Aged 18 years or older 2. Have been admitted for rehabilitation at The Angliss Hospital or Peter James Centre
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: 1. If admitted for geriatric evaluation and management 2. If they or their next of kin do not give informed consent to participate

trial_design.sequence: Permuted block randomisation stratified for site and casemix (neurological and other) generated by computerised sequence generation.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This trial will examine if providing additional therapy services on a Saturday reduces health care costs, and improves the health of hospital inpatients receiving rehabilitation compared to the usual Monday to Friday service.
